report_title: Fence and Scaffolding Rental Industry Report
executive_summary: The Fence and Scaffolding Rental industry is composed of companies that rent out scaffolding, fencing and other nonmechanical equipment to companies and contractors that are typically tied closely with downstream construction and maintenance markets. Nonresidential construction (i.e. offices, retail and entertainment buildings) accounts for nearly a third of the industry's revenue in 2022; the remainder is made up of municipal, industrial and commercial construction. Industry operators are strongly affected by trends within nonresidential construction, which is estimated to have suffered.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: - The value of private nonresidential construction is anticipated to decline an annualized 2.5% during the five-year period, significantly hindering industry revenue growth. - The value of residential construction is expected to increase an annualized 3.0% due to the low interest rate environment. - The amount of private spending on home improvement is expected to increase an annualized 2.5%. - Industry revenue is expected to decrease an annualized 7.4% to $1.4 billion over the five years to 2022. - Industry profit is also expected to decline due to comparatively higher wage costs and rising steel prices.

- Uninhibited downstream construction work and new nonresidential projects are anticipated to boost demand for fencing and scaffolding equipment. - A projected rise in government spending will likely increase demand from the industry's municipal segment. - The value of private nonresidential construction is anticipated to rise an annualized 2.5% in 2022. - Government consumption and investment are anticipated to rise an annualized 0.9% in 2022. - Industry revenue is expected to benefit from these recovering downstream markets and experience a rise of 1.4% in 2022.

- The value of nonresidential construction is expected to rapidly increase due to the complete economic reopening and large reductions in unemployment. - Mortgage rates are anticipated to gradually climb as the economy stabilizes post-pandemic, slowing activity within the residential construction sector and mitigating industry growth. - Overall, industry revenue is expected to decline an annualized 0.2% to $1.4 billion over the five years to 2027.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Residential construction and home improvement projects account for an estimated 40.1% of industry revenue; contractors often rent scaffolding and fencing for repair work (e.g. painting and roof tiling) on single-family homes and multifamily residences. Demand from this market has grown significantly over the past five years, primarily due to the Federal Reserve lowering interest rates in 2020 to combat the coronavirus induced recession.

The industry derives much of its revenue from nonresidential construction. An estimated 28.7% of revenue is generated through renting scaffolding and fences for commercial construction projects, including new construction and maintenance of office buildings, retail establishments, hospitality buildings and entertainment complexes. Another 22.6% of revenue is generated through infrastructure and municipal projects, while other construction, such as infrastructure and utilities, accounts for 8.3% of industry revenue.

Constrained performance and coronavirus-induced complications has decreased the number of new entrants into this industry. According to IBISWorld estimates, enterprises are projected to decrease at an annualized rate of 4.4% to 1,171 companies over the five years to 2022. However, many new entrants will likely seek to take advantage of the post-pandemic healthy economy, increased nonresidential work and new market niches.

The industry has also experienced increased demand from state, federal and local government entities over the current period. As a way to help create jobs, government entities have spent more federal funds on the maintenance

industry_definition: Companies in this industry install and rent out fencing and scaffolding equipment.
key_trends: The industry typically benefits from serving a wide range of downstream markets
New entrants also seek to take advantage of the current healthy economy
Low interest rates are another trend expected to support industry demand
Demand for higher-value scaffolding and fencing will likely continue to increase
The opportunity for new players to enter the industry will arise
External competition is also anticipated to rise, especially among homeowners
Uninhibited downstream construction work and new nonresidential projects are anticipated to boost demand for fencing and scaffolding equipment

market_segmentation.segment_description: Fencing and scaffolding rentals in the residential market account for an estimated 40.1% of industry revenue in 2022. Increased performance within this market buoyed industry demand during the five-year period, as low interest rates propelled the construction of new housing starts and increased private spending on home improvements.

Nonresidential commercial construction and maintenance accounts for an estimated 28.7% of industry revenue in 2022. This segment includes office buildings, retail establishments, hospitality establishments (e.g. hotels, motels and casinos) and entertainment buildings (e.g. theaters, cinemas and stadiums).

market_segmentation.segment: Infrastructure and municipal construction and maintenance
market_segmentation.segment_description: Demand from the infrastructure and municipal construction and maintenance market for fencing and scaffolding equipment has increased over the years accounting for 22.6% of industry revenue in 2022. This market includes religious buildings, schools, colleges and universities, hospitals, government buildings and public facilities.

Other markets that demand fencing and scaffolding rental services include industries such as building cleaners, industrial construction and various other contractors such as painters that use scaffolding to provide their services. However, this segment accounts for a small share of industry revenue since many of these contractors purchase fencing and scaffolding, as opposed to renting them.

products_and_services.product_description: Generally, scaffolding rental varies in cost between fixed, mobile or hanging scaffolding and depends upon the construction project engineering requirements and duration. Scaffoldings are usually rented for commercial and industrial construction as they are used to get access to heights and areas that would be otherwise hard to get to.

Fencing rentals are primarily used by commercial construction companies for worksite needs and on a more limited basis by households for special events. Fence panels are supported with counter-weighted feet, have a wide variety of accessories including gates, handrails, feet and bracing depending on the application.

Industry companies increasingly added other equipment rentals for construction projects over the past five years, such as hoists and lifts. These also include mast climbers, transportation platforms, personnel hoists and guided-material hoists that are primarily used for larger-scale commercial and industrial construction applications.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The nonresidential building construction market, which includes building and maintenance of retail, office, municipal and hospitality space, can determine the need for scaffolding contractors. Macroeconomic factors such as corporate profit, business sentiment, unemployment and value of construction influence demand from this market.

In the residential market, demand depends upon new local housing construction, household spending on housing improvements and per capita disposable income play an important role. For housing starts, macroeconomic factors that affect household demand for housing and housing affordability such as population and income growth, unemployment rates, home prices, mortgage rates all play a role in determining residential construction activity and associated demand for scaffolding rental.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast is the most-populated region in the United States and also has the highest concentration of industry companies. An estimated 25.9% of the total population lives in the Southeast, while an estimated 25.4% of total industry establishments are located in the region.

The West has the second-largest population and concentration of industry companies, with 17.2% of the population and 20.8% of industry establishments. California has the second-largest number of establishments in the nation, with 15.0% of total industry establishments due to its large residential real estate market and the presence of notable high-volume and high-value commercial and industrial real estate markets in San Francisco, Los Angeles and San Diego.

The Southwest is the next largest region, with 15.3% of industry establishments but only 12.9% of the population. There is a lower level of urbanization in this region, but a fast-growing population that is expanding its
Middle Atlantic region and its industry establishments.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Operators must comply with OSHA regulations on equipment use, worker safety, noise tolerance, protective clothing etc.
Operators are subject to EPA environmental and safety standards governing air pollution, noise, asbestos treatment etc.
Regulations were implemented to discourage public gatherings and unsafe work environments due to the coronavirus pandemic.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The revenue volatility level is very high.
The industry assistance level is low and steady.
The competition level is high and increasing.

factors_increased_barrier: The revenue volatility level is very high.
The competition level is high and increasing.
factors_decreased_barrier: The capital intensity level is low.
The market share concentration level is low.
The technology change level is low.
The globalization level is low and steady.

basis_points.basis_description: Competition is highly fragmented and regionally focused since the industry is primarily composed of small companies and individual contractors that provide a largely undifferentiated service.

The majority of companies compete for small commercial and residential construction projects in local markets whose level of competition varies depending upon volume and scale of local construction activity, supply of scaffolding and materials, proximity of establishments, and pricing conditions.
There are a few national competitors that principally compete for larger commercial projects.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The top four companies account for an estimated 14.7% of industry revenue in 2022.
The industry includes predominantly small-scale, geographically dispersed establishments that compete across a diverse range of construction activities.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The price of steel is anticipated to rise an annualized 4.7% over the five years to 2022, curtailing profitability.
Wages tend to be higher in this industry due to the level of physical labor and the dangerous nature of the work involved with the transportation of equipment.
Rental companies do incur costs on certain purchases of material and equipment on an as-needed basis to meet the criteria of a specific project.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: For every dollar spent on labor, the average operator dedicates $0.06 to capital expenses in 2022.
Companies must put forth a substantial portion of their revenue toward acquiring scaffolding, fences and related equipment.
Labor is an important component, accounting for 21.8% of revenue in 2022 for rental advice, transportation and support.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Industry revenue declined as much as 32.2% in 2020 amid the coronavirus pandemic and grew as much as 30.2% in 2021.
Large spikes in construction markets caused industry revenue volatility.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The nature of industry work is not subject to significant technological innovation, especially given the manual labor input.
Efforts to make scaffolds more lightweight and easier to assemble have placed some operators at an advantage.

FAQs.question: Does your company primarily work with residential or nonresidential construction markets? Can you easily switch between these markets?
FAQs.answer: Companies within the industry work extensively within both nonresidential and residential construction markets, providing rental products to any type of operator. Operators tend to work with whichever downstream market is doing better at time as they demand more industry services.

FAQs.question: Does your company lease primarily to consumers or businesses?
FAQs.answer: Operators within the industry tend to rent equipment to businesses for use in nonresidential and residential construction markets. Operators whom primarily provide services directly to consumers are those who tend to work more with do-it-yourselfers, who are conducting maintenance or additions on single-family homes.

FAQs.question: Have the rising prices of key construction inputs significantly affected profit margins in recent years?
FAQs.answer: Operators profit margins tend to rely on the price they can charge down stream construction markets, thus if downstream construction markets are diminished due to rising input prices, industry profit margins will struggle as well. Many industry operators rely heavily on the price of steel, to create the rent-able products, and the price of diesel, to transport said products.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition possibilities in locations with well-established, dynamic commercial markets?
FAQs.answer: Operators within the industry tend to be more localized due to the high weight of the rent-able products, therefore pulling up transport costs. Acquisition of other small localized firms would allow industry players to expand operations while avoiding long-distance transport costs.

FAQs.question: Does your company plan on investing in autonomous vehicles in the near future to reduce labor costs?
FAQs.answer: Wages take up a significant amount of costs for companies in this industry due to high levels of physical labor. The use of autonomous vehicles to move equipment in the warehouse and on to long-distance transport vehicles may significantly reduce labor costs.

FAQs.question: How much does your company spend on new technology annually? How does this compare with your competitors?
FAQs.answer: New lightweight industry equipment helps reduce transport costs and thus boost company profitability. Downstream consumers are more likely to rent from competitors who provide lighter and more up-to-date equipment.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met on and off the construction site?
FAQs.answer: Due to the highly physical nature of many jobs within the industry, employee injuries occur at a higher rate than other industries. Industry companies are required to adhere to OSHA and ANSI safety regulations, failure to comply may lead to heavy fines or lawsuits.

FAQs.question: Is your company adequately prepared for new environmental standards?
FAQs.answer: Environmental concerns have grown recently as construction projects become increasingly more complex. Failure to comply with new environmental standards may lead to health concerns and possible legal issues.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your customers renew their contracts?
FAQs.answer: Advertising is used very little within the industry, many companies gain new work from previous renters and word-of-mouth. Failure to renew clients will hurt a company's bottom-line significantly.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare with your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Company profit margins in this industry rely on the price of equipment purchased and their own price point. Profit margins are heavily determined how a company moves their rental price point as major construction commodity prices fluctuate.

FAQs.question: Do you have a strong reputation among customers? Are you known for your reliability and performance?
FAQs.answer: The majority of industry companies compete for work on a local basis; industry companies must secure loyal, repeat customers within their specific markets to compete successfully.

FAQs.question: What are your primary sources of revenue? What services are you hoping to offer in the future, and what investment will this require?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry can gain an advantage in the market by offering products for rent that are the latest design and model.

FAQs.question: How hard is it to promote your company by word-of-mouth recommendations? How many of your clients were referred to you?
FAQs.answer: Much of the work generated in this market comes from referrals from satisfied clients. An operator must establish a sound reputation for quality and timeliness to obtain long-term success.

FAQs.question: How does the government consumption affect your revenue? How do win government contracts?
FAQs.answer: Government spending on education, healthcare and community programs drives demand for scaffolding and fences used in school, hospital, community building and other institutional construction projects.

FAQs.question: How much of you business is derived from the residential market? How can you boost demand from this segment?
FAQs.answer: Much of the industry's revenue is generated from the provision of scaffolding equipment to the housing market. Contractors typically rent scaffolding for smaller projects during the repair, maintenance and new construction of single-family homes.

FAQs.question: How does increased nonresidential construction affect demand? How do you plan to prepare for declines in this market?
FAQs.answer: Private investment in nonresidential structures includes new construction and renovations of commercial, industrial, educational and religious establishments. The industry derives a substantial share of its revenue from renting equipment to general contractors that work on these structures.
